title: The Wolf Ritual in the old days

utterances.translation: This happened a very long time ago.
Then Europeans had not arrived yet.
A long time ago a Wolf Ceremony was held.
They had a feast at night.
The man spoke, saying that there is going to be a Wolf Ceremony.
“Very well,” the high-ranking person said.

transcript.default: ʔiiḥp̓iit waa, ʔaya. ʔayaʔatḥitwaʔiš manuuisʔatḥ huuʔak

utterances.translation: The high-ranking person said, “Once there were many Manhousats:
There were more than five hundred [households].”

transcript.default: hišuusʔaɬ ʔaatḥiy̓u hiiɬ ʔink ḥaaɬ ʔappiʔiɬʔi ʔink.

utterances.translation: At night all the people are in the house, and there was a fire blazing at the center of the house.
Now, wolves (people acting as wolves) surrounded the house [making a howling sound with wolf whistles].

transcript.default: qʷaamitiiʔaaɬ huuʔak hitaatamitʔaɬ ɬuucsamiiḥ, qʷaaʔiitq y̓uuqʷaa čaakupiiḥ nuutiic. hitaʔatap ʔustpitap.

utterances.translation: A long time ago women, as well as men, used to take off the headbans and put them on the floor.

transcript.default: č̓iḥiy̓ap t̓iʔuup ʔuuštup qʷaaʔiitq, ʔaqʔištiik, ƛ̓učum.

utterances.translation: The fire was extinguished by throwing something, such as blue mussels.
The fire was smothered.
The wolf crawled in.
Women were chanting [in middle high voice].
The son of the chief was taken on the fourth time around.
The wolves took him out and went out of the Big House.
People heard them (the wolves) howling behind the village.
The wolves were making strange sounds.
The wolf was among the human beings [taking the human shape, so people didn’t know which of them were wolves].
Now it became daylight.

transcript.default: ʔiiqḥuk̓ʷaƛ ḥaw̓iɬʔi ʔin ʔukʷaaɬ, ʔukʷaaɬ, ḥaaw̓iɬaƛ̓i.

utterances.translation: The chief told his people that his son was missing.
It became daylight.
This is the place for the Wolf Ceremony. {with picture}
There is a place here for the Wolf Ceremony.
There is another forbidden place, _siixpaackum_, and they (the wolves) would come out here.

transcript.default: n̓aacsiičiƛ qʷayac̓iikm̓inḥʔi, ʔuuštup hiɬačišt tup̓aɬ ʔaya qʷaaƛaa hiiɬtqyaap̓aɬʔi.

utterances.translation: They (village people) saw wolves and many things in the sea and also behind the village.
The wolves grabbed away and took the young man through the water to the shore. They swam ashore on the rock.
He was taken away by many.
There was a precipice behind the village: it was high, it was probably high.
Again the Wolves howled four times.

transcript.default: heey maasuuɬšiƛ y̓uuqʷaa kʷiisḥinatuk. awayaatukʷitii, [uuː uuː uuː uuː].

utterances.translation: _Wooo_, they also howled in a strange way. They sounded like this …
The chief acted strangely. (There was something wrong with the chief.)
He noticed something was wrong [about his ritual].
They (the wolves) kept coming down to the place where they do their ritual.
The wolves howled again. The wolves were many.
Then, they spoke to him.

transcript.default: huuʔak ʔuyi qʷaackʷiyii naʔaackʷi qʷayac̓iik ʔuukʷiɬ quuquuʔas, qʷaaq siy̓a, quuʔas qʷaaʔiitk. naʔaa.

utterances.translation: A long time ago wolves could understand human beings just as you and I do.
This was also true with birds.
They (animals and humans) understand each other.
They (the wolves and the young man) went up behind the hill.
They departed and headed far away.
Those people who stayed at home continued the ritual.
They did the Wolf Ceremony with another person taking the place of the young man [who had been taken away by the wolves].
Then people saw a young man paddling in a canoe.
And the wolf slapped it (the young man’s canoe) [on the side].
It (the canoe) came from the forbidden place.
It was the other young man. It might have been the younger brother.

transcript.default: qaɬaatik waaʔat [younger brother], taayii waaʔat m̓aam̓iiqsu [oɬder brother].

utterances.translation: We say _qaɬaatik_ for “younger brother” and _taayii_ or _m̓aam̓iiqsu_ for “older brother”.
Now then, the wolves took off.
And the people finished the Wolf Ceremony.

transcript.default: ʔiiqḥuk̓ʷaƛ ʔin hiniicc̓iʔat qʷayac̓iik, qʷayaac̓iksaʔi, saštupʔi čamiḥta.

utterances.translation: He (the chief) told his people that his son was taken by a pack of wolves, the real wolves, the real animals [not the ceremonial performers].
The wolves [taking human shape] hid [among the people], and they (the people) didn’t know which one was a [real] person.
The Wolf Ritual was a very serious matter.
They went over the hill to Gold River (Muchalat land).
The Machalat people would hear the young man chanting his song.
They (Muchalats) heard Manhousat songs.

transcript.default: waa ʔucačiƛ ḥuuɬ t̓ašiis. t̓ašiis. yaaqʷiɬqin Tahsis waa. Sawmill hiɬʔiitq.

utterances.translation: And then they went over to _t̓ašiis_, a place we call [in English] Tahsis, where there was a sawmill.
They went over [the high land] to Odlaqutla.
He knew where he was all the time (he was familiar with all places on the way).
Odlaqutla is where Nuchalath lived before [They moved from their original habitat].

transcript.default: hiʔacačit̓išʔaɬ ƛah nučaaɬʔatḥ ʔiqʔiiʔas, histaqšiƛ nučaaɬ.

utterances.translation: Now the Nuchalath people went back to the same place — where they had originally moved from, i.e. _nučaaɬ_.
They heard the wolves that were remaining there for a long time — it could have been four days.

transcript.default: hinʔay̓aqƛ ʔin ʔuyaa hiitkin, hiitkin n̓aas.

utterances.translation: The people were alert because it was peculiar and strange — it was a strange day every day .

transcript.default: ʔaaḥʔasa wiiʕaqƛ̓aɬ hišuk, wiiʕaqƛ hinaasʔat, hinaas, ʔin ʔuusḥhii qʷayac̓iikʔi.

utterances.translation: They all seemed to be sad and worried about the man because there was something strange about the wolves.
They went to Kyuquot at the head of the bay going out of the inlet.
Then they went to Ououkinish Inlet and Checleset Bay.
He used to sing his song at night.

transcript.default: ʕac̓ikšiƛ ḥaaw̓iɬaƛ̓i č̓aʔuy̓ic qʷiʔiiʔitq qʷayac̓iikʔi, muwač.

utterances.translation: The young man learned to eat raw food that wolves would eat, such as deer meat.
Deer meat was his main food.

transcript.default: waa ʔuʔiic ƛ̓aqapt. ƛ̓aqapt yaaqʷiɬ mamaɬn̓i herbs waa ʔuʔiic haʔuk.

utterances.translation: And he ate plants. Plants, or “herbs” as the white men call them, he ate them.

transcript.default: wik̓aƛquuč ʔaaʔaayaqƛapi, ʔumaak ʔaḥ p̓usšiƛquu, tuxʷiiḥaquu, ʔin ƛ̓ay̓ix qʷayac̓iik. ʔin ƛ̓ay̓ix.

utterances.translation: He wouldn’t eat too much so as not to get tired or get out of breath: because wolves were swift.
They (the wolves) move their feet fast, but they don’t run.
The young man was swift on [all] fours like wolves.
He kept us with them (the wolf pack).

transcript.default: muutwiiʔiɬuk. qʷaa y̓uuqʷaa ʔaƛakʷaɬ. hiɬʔapʔat ʔaḥ ʔappiʔiɬʔi.

utterances.translation: [In the pack] there were four [wolves] in the front and also eight [behind] — they put him (the young man) in the center of the pack.

transcript.default: ḥaʔiḥtisʔaƛ čaʔakʔi, nuučaan̓uɬʔi, waa huʔacačiƛ ʔiqsčiik huʔap̓in.

utterances.translation: He reached the tip of the island (= Vancouver Island) and the mountain range, and then they came back to the starting point, following the same route.

transcript.default: waa ʔucačiʔaƛ hiy̓atḥuusitii ʕuc̓uusʔatḥ, ʕuc̓uusʔatḥ, w̓apuukḥ.

utterances.translation: And then they went back to places where the young man lived, Otsosat and _w̓apuukḥ_.

transcript.default: hitawiiʔis qucačiʔaƛ ƛaʔuukʷiʔatḥ, Clayoquot waa, ƛaʔuukʷiʔatḥ.

utterances.translation: They went down to the inlet to Clayoquot.
All the bands had heard about them.
They reached the [other] tip of the isle, to Nitinaht.
The only time they stopped was when it got dark.
They travled along mountain ranges, steep hills, steep valleys, and vertical cliffs.
The wolves traveled and could see high peaks far, far away.

transcript.default: ʔaḥʔaaʔaƛ hinaɬačiʔaƛ [Full Moon] waaʔatquu miɬmy̓uuƛ hupaɬ.

utterances.translation: Then the moon began to wax (the new moon cycle had begun): Full Moon, you could say; the moon was perfectly round.
They didn’t have to stop for long distances.
The journey had been continuing for a long time. And it had been four months [since they had departed].
They traveled along the coast for four months.

transcript.default: čuu, wiinapuʔaƛ ʔuušsaac̓u hiɬḥitii ʕaʔuk ʔiiḥ ʕaʔukʷaq wiinapuƛ̓aɬ.

utterances.translation: Then they made stops at places where there was a big lake.

transcript.default: ʔuyiiʔaƛ̓atquuč tiičma ḥaaw̓iɬaƛ̓aɬ ʔuʔiic̓ap̓at tiičma muwač, waa ḥismisukʔ muwač ʔuʔiič naqšiʔaƛquuč.

utterances.translation: The young man was given a heart of a deer to eat, and he drank deer blood.
Each time he was fed first, and then the wolves ate.
The wolves would stop by the shoreline of a like, a big lake.

transcript.default: haaʔumtaqaƛquuč, ʔunaak qʷayac̓iikʔi ƛ̓ay̓ix. ƛ̓ay̓ix muukmuukʷa.

utterances.translation: When the wolves hunted, they sent the ones that ran fastest.
It didn’t take them long to catch a deer and kill it, or ‘put it to sleep’.
Don’t say “kill”.
Never say “kill” when you kill animals.

transcript.default: qʷaa y̓uuqʷaa ʕaḥmis. wiiy̓aat qaḥsaap waaʔat,

utterances.translation: It is the same with mammals. Never say “kill”.
Say “You become tame!” or “I will make you tame.”
Wolves would say that lisping.
“_ʔuʔiič̓eepiks_, _ʔuʔiič̓eepiks_” — that is how wolves would talk.

transcript.default: wik qʷaa qʷaaqin čamiḥta niiw̓a ciiqciiqa ʔuʕiičiʔatikqs.

utterances.translation: They are unlike us who speak properly as “_ʔuʕiičiʔatikqs_”.
We will say, “_ʔuʕiičiʔatikqs_.”
And wolves lisp like “_ʔuʔiič̓eetiks_, _ʔuʔiič̓eetiks_.”
The wolves sound as if they are lisping.
Now they departed.
They went to a seaside village called Ohiat and stayed there for quite a while.

transcript.default: naʔaa ḥaw̓iɬʔi, hišuk, qum̓uusʔiq maamaḥt̓i, qum̓aaqƛ̓asʔitq.

utterances.translation: [And] the chief and everybody — every member of every household in the village — heard them [howling and singing].

transcript.default: naʔaa, tuuḥukʔaɬ ʔin hiitkin qʷayac̓iikʔi, woo=kʷiisḥinatuk maasuuɬšiʔaƛquu.

utterances.translation: They heard him (the wolves) and got afraid because the wolves were strange, making strange noise when they howled.
They sounded like this for four times: _woo_.
This is how they sounded and they did it four times.
“It’s very strange,” they said.
They knew that the young man had a name (the young man had been initiated).
The young man had changed, getting swift in action, and he didn’t have any serious competition [against him].
[When he ran in the woods] it was as if he ran through bushes.
Tree branches [that would obstruct the path] would get out of his way.

transcript.default: qʷaa y̓uuqʷaa ḥaaɬ ʔuw̓as suč̓as ḥimqšiƛ.

utterances.translation: So would the windfalls — they would move out of their way.
The same with the thickets — they would be folded down on the ground.

transcript.default: qʷis ʔaḥʔaa suč̓as t̓aḥʔiƛ ḥacaqc̓inƛ ʔaḥ.

utterances.translation: Trees, too, are bent all the way down to the ground [with their tops touching the ground].
He could see the other side of the channel.
It was very close to this place where we are now, Victoria.
Makah was very close [to Victoria].
[But] it has changed and now we are far apart [from Makah]. Something extraordinary happened.
Nitinahts could hear them.

utterances.translation: Many Nitinaht people knew about their predecessors and this story — or mythology, as white men call it now.
A long, long time ago, things were accurate.
He returned all the way along the same trail.

People said “one day” [when they meant “one year”] a long time ago.

utterances.translation: _n̓upqʔičḥ_ is “one year”: It’s equal to one year.
_n̓upčiiɬ_ is “one day”.

utterances.translation: It was not high over the hill, it couldn’t be that high up — like three hundred feet high.
They (people in the Big House) were surrounded by the wolves.
They were also at the creek.
Wolves were there so that people could not get water.
They (village people) were all prepared [for the return of the wolves].

utterances.translation: At the beginning of a new year, which white men call December, they came back.
The chiefs sang songs and beat their drums.

utterances.translation: [In the fireplace in the Big House], There were no flames — only sparks.
There was something extraordinary about the fire.
The knot [burning in the fireplace] was still showing flashes [even after a long time].
The knot appeared to be the same all the time — it only showed little flashes — or flames, you could say.
The knots remained the same in the fireplace.

utterances.translation: They could barely recognize people sitting together in the Big House — however big the house was.
Right here in the house there was fire, burning. {GL indicated the position by drawing a picture.}
In the house there was one door right here. {GL indicated the position by drawing a picture.}
They had eight people on top of the house as lookouts.
The wolves would circle around the house four times.
Now, they went into the woods.
Now, it became daylight on the fourth day.

utterances.translation: The wolves crawled out of the woods to the rocky point.
The best hunters were there, coming from everywhere.
The hunters threw spears and they aimed their spears at his shoulder.
Spears might have [penetrated his skin and] scraped his bone [but they didn’t make any serious damage on the bone].
[Whenever the young man got wounded,] the wolves immediately licked the wound.
It seems as though they had medicine.
[Then] It (his wound) stopped bleeding, and it didn’t even swell.
They (wolves) were having problems [with responding to the attack against them] being in the canoe. It was difficult.
The wolves jumped into the water.
People tried to club the wolves, but the wolves would bite the clubs and take them away.
People captured him (the young man). They started the ritual all over again.
They didn’t know where those wolves had gone in the woods.

_woo_ _woo_ _woo_ _woo_ — this is how they sounded.
The young man was taken away.

utterances.translation: “Listen,” the elder said, “Do not tell whatever they have done to you to anybody for one year. You will be away for one year.”
The young man was taken away so that he could not do anything [that ordinary people can do].
